pullRequest.body:
This adds a file `NumberTheory.LSeries.Linearity`, which contains statements on
* addition (moved from `NumberTheory.LSeries.Basic`)
* negation and
* scalar multiplication

of L-series, and corresponding statements for `LSeries.term`, `LSeriesHasSum` and `LSeriesSummable`.

See [this thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/L-series/near/424858837) on Zulip.


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Changed names to be namespaced (and thus enabling dot notation) - thanks!

(I would plead for an exception to the lowerCamelCase rule for `LSeries...`, as the `L` is always upper case in informal math.)

> Changed names to be namespaced (and thus enabling dot notation) - thanks!
> 
> (I would plead for an exception to the lowerCamelCase rule for `LSeries...`, as the `L` is always upper case in informal math.)

LGTM! I also think the L should be upper case, but I'll let the maintainers decide.

> (This PR does make me wonder whether we should be supporting `LSeries` valued in other spaces than `â„‚`, perhaps in a normed `â„‚`-vector space. This could come in useful, e.g. Iwasawa theorists like me are very fond of equivariant L-functions taking values in a group ring `â„‚[G]` where `G` is the Galois group of some finite extension. But it might have downsides in terms of making the API less convenient for the â€“ undeniably most important â€“ case of `â„‚` coefficients.)

I think it makes sense to try to get a reasonably complete set-up for complex-valued L-series first, and worry about generalizing it later. I don't expect a lot of problems with replacing `â„‚` as the target by a normed `â„‚`-vector space (or normed `â„‚`-algebra when talking about convolution).

I'm happy with the current naming setup, and nobody else seems to have objected to it on the zulip thread, so let's get this in.

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8247758427/job/22556611466)

Upper-case types should be camelCased in theorem names, except in namespaces:
Upper-case types should be camelCased in theorem names, except in namespaces:

I left a couple of small golfing comments. Otherwise looks good. 

(This PR does make me wonder whether we should be supporting `LSeries` valued in other spaces than `â„‚`, perhaps in a normed `â„‚`-vector space. This could come in useful, e.g. Iwasawa theorists like me are very fond of equivariant L-functions taking values in a group ring `â„‚[G]` where `G` is the Galois group of some finite extension. But it might have downsides in terms of making the API less convenient for the â€“ undeniably most important â€“ case of `â„‚` coefficients.)

```suggestion
lemma LSeriesHasSum.neg {f : â„• â†’ â„‚} {s a : â„‚} (hf : LSeriesHasSum f s a) :
```

```suggestion
lemma LSeriesSummable.neg {f : â„• â†’ â„‚} {s : â„‚} (hf : LSeriesSummable f s) :
```

```suggestion
lemma LSeriesSummable.neg_iff {f : â„• â†’ â„‚} {s : â„‚} :
```

```suggestion
lemma LSeries.neg (f : â„• â†’ â„‚) (s : â„‚) : LSeries (-f) s = -LSeries f s := by
```

```suggestion
lemma LSeriesHasSum.smul {f : â„• â†’ â„‚} (c : â„‚) {s a : â„‚} (hf : LSeriesHasSum f s a) :
```

```suggestion
lemma LSeriesSummable.smul {f : â„• â†’ â„‚} (c : â„‚) {s : â„‚} (hf : LSeriesSummable f s) :
```

```suggestion
lemma LSeriesSummable.of_smul {f : â„• â†’ â„‚} {c s : â„‚} (hc : c â‰  0)
```
and add `LSeriesSummable.smul_iff` (or `iff_smul`?)

```suggestion
lemma LSeries.smul (f : â„• â†’ â„‚) (c s : â„‚) : LSeries (c â€¢ f) s = c * LSeries f s := by
```
You can probably set f,g and some of a,b,c,s as implicit variables at the top and save having to create them each time.
I don't think this would be an improvement (see [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/'variable'.20-.20style.20question/near/425503092)).

```suggestion
  Â· simp only [term_of_ne_zero (Nat.succ_ne_zero _), Pi.add_apply, add_div]
```

```suggestion
  âŸ¨of_smul hc, smul câŸ©
```
Is `smul_apply` perhaps a better name?

Maybe. But then it should also be `LSeries.add_apply` and `LSeries.neg_apply`, and one could have
```lean
lemma LSeries.smul (f : â„• â†’ â„‚) (c : â„‚) : LSeries (c â€¢ f) = c â€¢ LSeries f := ...
lemma LSeries.neg (f : â„• â†’ â„‚) : LSeries (-f) = -LSeries f := ...
```
This does not work for `add`, however, because of possibly differing convergence behaviour.

On the other hand, the other statements (`LSeries.term_smul`, `LSeriesHasSum.smul`, `LSeriesSummable.smul` etc.) all include the `s` argument, so the present version is reasonably consistent (and `LSeries.term_smul_apply` adds the `n` argument, not the `s` argument...).

But `LSeriesSummable` and `LSeriesHasSum` are `Prop`s, while `LSeries` contains data, so the situation is not quite comparable. I would have expected `LSeries.smul` to be a map `â„‚ â†’ LSeries â†’ LSeries` that defines the scalar multiplication operation on `LSeries` (by analogy with `Nat.add` etc). 

(EDIT: What I wrote doesn't quite make sense, since `LSeries` is a function outputting terms of type `â„‚ â†’ â„‚`, it's not a type in its own right. But still the name feels odd and jarring compared to conventions elsewhere in mathlib. Perhaps `map_smul` might make more sense?)

PS: Possibly a better comparison is that there is `HasSum.const_smul` and `Summable.const_smul`, but there is no `tsum.const_smul`; there are no lemmas in the `tsum` namespace, because the output of `tsum` is a number, it doesn't have type `tsum ...`, so you can't dot-notate on it.

In fact this suggests (to me) that the naming convention `LSeries.foo` is misguided for all values of `foo` (not just `add`, `smul` etc), and they should all be `LSeries_foo` or indeed `lseries_foo`.

@Ruben-VandeVelde suggested the change from `LSeries_smul` to `LSeries.smul` (and the same for `neg`) a few days ago.
I don't have strong feelings either way, but I would like to have some kind of consensus here, so that we can move on...

> In fact this suggests (to me) that the naming convention `LSeries.foo` is misguided for all values of `foo` (not just `add`, `smul` etc), and they should all be `LSeries_foo` or indeed `lseries_foo`.

Enabling dot notation is not the only reason to put stuff in namespaces, though. My understanding is that this also serves as an organising principle (e.g., in a currently active Zulip thread, it is dicsussed to introduce a `Discrete` namespace to serve as a home for statements on discrete Fourier transform etc., even though there won't be things of type `Discrete ...` to which they apply).

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/LSeries/Linearity): move/add statements on linearity of L-series
